titleStmt.title: Acteon & Diana with a pastoral storie of the nimph Oenone followed by the several conceited humours of Bumpkin the huntsman, Hobbinal the shepherd, Singing Simpkin, and John Swabber the seaman / by Rob. Cox, acted at the Red Bull with great applause.
titleStmt.author: Cox, Robert, d. 1655.

editionStmt.edition: The second edition, with the addition of Simpleton the smith, not before extant.

note.p: Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

projectDesc.p: Header created with script marc2tei.pl on 2001-12-12.

editorialDecl.p: Encoding has been done using the recommendations for Level 4 of the TEI in Libraries Guidelines. Digital page images are linked to the text file.

div.head: ACTEON & DIANA.
div.stage: Enter the first Huntsman, and Bumpkin very Melancholy.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.l: BUt tell me fellow Bumpkin, what's the matter?
Thou that hast formerly been heard to sing
As merily and sweetly as the Cuckowe,
But by the posture thou dost now appear in,
Strangers will sooner take thee for an Asse,
Then for a man of mettle.

sp.speaker: Bumpkin.
sp.l: It may be so.
sp.p: And for my owne part, I am not such a fool, to think the contrary; nay, I would change condition with an Asse, and thank him too: never was any man (of parts) so tumbled, Jumbled and Rumbled, as poor Bumpkin is.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Bumpkin.
sp.p: Nay, I know not, but every day my great guts and my small guts makes such a combustion in my belly as passes, and my puddings (like Lances) runs a tilt at my heart, and makes me as queasie stomackt as a young Green-sickness girl newly come to a big belly.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.p: Canst thou not guess the reason of this trouble.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p:
Yes, I think I can, and Ile be judged by thee,
if my case bee not desperate: I have a horrible minde to be in Love.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.p: With whom.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: With any body, but I cannot find out the way how to be in Love.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.p: Why? Ile instruct thee: canst thou be Melancholly?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Yes, as a dog, or a hoglouse, I could even finde in my heart, to cry presently.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.p: Canst thou sleep well?

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: I cannot tell, I never saw my self sleep.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.l: Is't possible, that thou who hast so long
Been an attendant on my Lord Acteon.
Shouldst be to learn the way to be in Love.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: I would it were not possible, on the condition thou wert hanged and quartered.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, but Bumpkin list to me,
This day thou knowest the maids and youngmen meet
To sport, and revell it about the May-pole;
Present thy self there, tell thy cause of grief,
And I dare warrant thee a sweet-heart presently.

sp.speaker: Hump.
sp.p: If thou canst do that, Ile marry her first, and learn to love her afterwards.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.p: Hast thither Bumpkin, Ile go on before.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: And I will follow there a dog trot.
sp.p: Is it not pitty, that a man of Authority as I am, having been chief dog-keeper to my Lord Acteon this five years, being a man so comely of person, and having such a pure complexion, that all fair Ladyes may be ashamed to look on me, and that I should be distressed for a sweet-heart:
sp.l: Maypole I com, & if the wenches there increas my pains
And scorn to Love, Ile beat out all their braines.

div.stage: Enter the Huntsmen, with three Country Wenches, as they come in, they sing this song.

lg.l: COme you youngmen, come along.
With your Musique, dance and song;
Bring your Lasses in your hands,
For 'tis that which Love commands:
Then to the Maypole come away,
For it is now a Holiday.
It is the choice time of the year,
For the Vi'lets now appear;
Now the Rose receives its birth,
And prettie Primrose decks the earth:
Then to the Maypole come away,
For it is now a Holiday.
Here each Batchelor may chuse
One that will not saith abuse,
Nor repay with coy disdain,
Love, that should be lov'd again:
Then to the Maypole, &c.
And when you well reckoned have,
What kisses you your sweethearts gave,
Take them all again, and more,
It will never make them poor:
Then to the Maypole, &c.
When you thus have spent the time,
Till the day be past its prime,
To your beds repaire at night,
And dream there of your dayes delight:
Then to the Maypole come away,
For it is now a Holiday.

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wench.
sp.p: It is possible, would Bumpkin be in Love?

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.l: Yes, if he knew but how, and for that sicknes
I have undertaken to become his doctor;
For, at the Maypole meeting 'tis decreed
A sweet heart must be purchast, come what will on't.

sp.speaker: 3. Co. Wench.
sp.p: Nay, if he be distressed, twenty to one he may find charitable persons there.

sp.speaker: 1. Co. Wench.
sp.l: What Lasse to such a writhled fac'd companion;
One that by's looks, shewes that his fathers orchard
Could yield no fruit, but Crabs or Apple-Johns:
Should he be granted a prevailing suitor,
I should not think it requisite or fitting
Women hereafter should enjoy their eyes;
Their very tongues too should be put to silence,
Onely allowed to rail at that vile person,
Who by her choice of him, sham'd the whole sex.

sp.speaker: 2. Co.
sp.l: Nay, I would lay a heavier curse upon her,
She should not sleep without a wanton dream,
And waking find no hopes of what she dream'd.

sp.speaker: 2. Hunt.
sp.l: That was a heavie curse and well con|sider'd,
But could you find our fellow Bumpkins parts.

sp.speaker: 3. Co. Wench.
sp.p: He can loose none, and who can finde them then.

sp.speaker: 3. Hunt.
sp.p: Do you beleeve him foolish.

sp.speaker: 1. Co. Wench.
sp.p: It is a faith that needs no confirmation.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.p: Laugh at him then, and wee'l assist you in't; but do't with Consideration.

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wench.
sp.p: So we will,—hark Lasses.

sp.speaker: 2. Hunt.
sp.p: Now if they be not hatching Eggs of mischief, let me be counted addle, what think you sirs?

div.stage: Country Wenches Laugh, Ha ha ha,

sp.speaker: 1. Co. Wench.
sp.l: And if he have not love enough, good Cupid,
Let me want Love when look't for.

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wench.
sp.l: In the mean time
Let us not starve our pastimes, pray sirs,
Being the Maypole revels.

sp.speaker: 3. Hunt.
sp.l: So we will;
Come strike up a farewell to misfortune.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Thats a dance that I could never hit off, Pray desist a while and hear my dolefull tale.

sp.speaker: 1. Co. Wench.
sp.p: Hee'l make us cry sure.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Be it known unto all men by these presents

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wench.
sp.p: An obligation; wee'l be no witnesses.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Why then ile hang my self?

sp.speaker: 3. Co. Wench.
sp.p: We will be witness then.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: What to my hanging? O my conscience! If I should woo my heart out, I should never be the fatter, for it.—where's your promise now?

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.p: You have not yet exprest your self, be plain, Tell them your grief, a remedy will follow.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: If that be all, 'tis but an easie matter, pray take notice that I am in Love—with somebody.

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wench.
sp.p: Would I were she!

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Why? so you are, if you have a minde to't

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wench.
sp.p: Why then you are my own?

sp.speaker: 3. Co. W.
sp.p: Pardon me, sister, I They all hang about him. bespake him yesterday.

sp.speaker: Bump
sp.p: Yes marry did she.

sp.speaker: 1. Co. Wench.
sp.p: But I was she that won him at the Maypole.

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wench.
sp.p: Was that the cause you strove so for the Garland.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: What's that to you?
Would I had any one of them in quietness.

sp.speaker: 3. Co. Wench.
sp.p: But yet I must have share.

sp.speaker: 1. Co. Wench.
sp.p: So must I too.

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wench.
sp.p: I will not part without the better half.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Then who shall have me whole, what are you mad?

sp.speaker: 3. Co. Wench.
sp.p: There's reason for a madness in this case.

sp.speaker: 1. Co. Wench.
sp.p: I will not lose my right. Let go I say.

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wen.
sp.l: He shall be mine, or else he shall be nothing.

sp.speaker: Bumpkin.
sp.l: Away you Burrs, why do you stick thus on me?
Now by this hand, if nothing can perswade you
Ile drown my self for spight that you may perish.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.l: Hark, hark, my Lord Acteons warning piece,
That Horne gives us intelligence he does intend
To spend this day in hunting, Bumpkin, why stay you?
The hounds will quarrell with you, wee'l come after.

sp.speaker: 1. Co. Wench.
sp.p: Will you not stay my Love.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Ile see you hang'd first, and by this hand ere I will be in love again, Ile feed my hounds with my own proper carcase.

sp.speaker: 2. Co. Wench.
sp.p: Now he is gon, our dancing may go forward.

sp.speaker: 2. Hunt.
sp.p: My Lord Acteon stayes, be quick, I pray.

sp.speaker: 3. Co. Wench.
sp.p: Quick as you will, the doing of it quick makes it shew better.

sp.speaker: Acteon▪
sp.l: ARe all the hounds uncoupled, let the woods,
Vallies, and hils, be fild with their sweet musick:
Till the thick Aire pierc't by their harmony,
Return a willing Ecchoe; Let your cunning
And care in this dayes hunting be exprest,
To make the world know that Acteons pleasure,
Is honoured and obeyed, be nimble sirrah.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Nimble? yes, as a Bear that hath been lug'd to purpose: if Love be such a troublesome Companion, I will intreat him to keep out of my company.

sp.speaker: Acteon.
sp.l: Where are your fellows? we consume the day
That should be spent in sport, with idleness.
Go find them out, and tell them of my purpose.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: They have sav'd me a labour.

sp.speaker: Acteon.
sp.l: Fie! what mean you?
The glory of this day calls us to action:
The wild inhabitans of these fair woods,
Are to be instructed, they must fear our Javelins,
Our sloath will make them careless.

sp.speaker: 1. Hunt.
sp.l: Sir, you may please to know, that yesternight
I lodg'd a Boar within the neighbouring Forrest.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.l: Yes Sir, and I lodg'd a Fox at a house hard by.

sp.speaker: Hunt.
sp.l: His foamy tushes did proclaim defiance
To all that would oppose him, his vast length
And breadth of wonder, caus'd me to beleeve
These woods nere bred his equall.

sp.speaker: Acteon.
sp.l: He's then a worthy subject for my javelin,
Whose glittering head Ile bath so long within him,
Till I have dy'd it Crimson with his blood;
Nor shall Diana's self, who every day
Honours these woods with her fair train of Nymphs,
Have power to ravish from my resolute arm,
The glory of this conquest: in the mean time,
Let musicks sweet tunes in our breasts create
Desire of Acteon, whilst our active Feet,
Nimbly beguiles our duller thoughts of power
To contradict our pleasures: in the fall
Of this wild Boar, lies honour for us all.

div.stage: A dance with Acteon and his Huntsmen.
A dance of Diana and her Nymphs, in the later end of which Acteon and his Huntsmen joyn with them, upon which Diana sayes,

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: This boldness ruines thee.

sp.speaker: Act.
sp.l: Ile follow though my ruine do attend me,

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: The unbridled boldness of Acteons youth,
Merits a punishment to equalize
The nature of his crime; sawcy young man,
Too much presuming of thy known deserts,
Be witness you that have vowd chastitie,
How much he hath endeavoured to eclipse
The glory of our puritie; for to me
And those that are my Votaries, honors precepts
Must strictly be observed; no Balm can cure
The wound of Reputation when 'tis made
Upon those bosoms that are vowd to vertue.
Shall she resolve his ruine?

sp.speaker: 1. Nymph.
sp.l: Gracious Madam,
Mercy with chastity and beauty joyn'd,
Are both with Gods and Men in estimation,
And though his fault beyond expression great,
Cries lowdly on your wrath to execute,
Yet let his youth find pardon.

sp.speaker: 2. Nymph.
sp.l: It will prove your charity unequalled.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: Your goodness shall
Become example to my willing pitie:
Therefore if young Acteon from this time,
Consider his own safety and my honor,
My vengeance shall be silent; but if agen
He shall presume to tempt his most sad fate,
Ruine as quick as lightning shal demolish
What Nature did erect in him for wonder,
That so from men this truth may not be hid,
No one must covet what the Gods forbid:
Undress you now, for by this fountain side.
Our garments from our bodies wee'l divide.

sp.speaker: Acteon.
sp.l: What wonders do I gaze on? Might I thus
Be feasted at my eyes till time grow old,
I would not wish a satisfaction
Of any other sense:—Unkind Diana,
To be so much a miser of thy beauties.
Loves laws can not be perfect, till they part
Rebellion from the confines of thy heart.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.l: We are betraid! Oh Chastity defend us.

sp.speaker: Acteon.
sp.l: Twas but a flattring bliss that did me cherish.
Fly, fly, Acteon, lest thy life do perish.

sp.speaker: Di.
sp.l: Fool! thinkst thou to escape? Know that my will
Has power to reach, though thou bestrid'st a wind,
And as by hunting thy offence grew high,
So by the hands of Hunters thou shalt die.
My will prevails, his head is circled round,
The largest Hart ere beat the Forrest ground.
And now forbear this fountain from henceforth,
Let my dishonour dwell upon the Spring,
The waters be corrupted, choakt with mud,
Foul and infectious, like to Lethes flood.

div.p: Where Acteon comes transformed into the shape of a Hart, his Huntsmen pursue him, and in the conclusion kill him, and bear him away.
